metadata.case_name: Messrs George Restaurant and Stores v. Union of India

facts.text: Petitioners are 5 citizens of India carrying on business of running a restaurant and general stores under the name and style of Messrs George Restaurant and Stores at 20, Apollo Street, Fort, Bombay-1, since September 1958 as a registered partnership firm under the Indian Partnership Act.
The firm employs 43 persons, including cooks, waiters, tea-makers, bill clerks and two store-clerks. Besides paying salary, petitioners give employees free food and other personal allowances.

Central Government issued Notification No. G.S.R. 704 dated May 16, 1961 under s.1(3)(b) of Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952, directing that with effect from June 30, 1961, the Act shall apply to hotels and restaurants in each of which twenty or more persons are employed.
As a result of the notification, the Act extended to hotels and restaurants including the one run by petitioners.

Central Government issued Notification S.R.O. 783 under s.5 read with s.7(1) making Employees Provident Funds (Third Amendment) Scheme, 1961, inserting sub-clause (xviii) in clause (b) of sub-paragraph (3) of paragraph 1 of Employees Provident Fund Scheme, 1952, for hotels and restaurants covered by G.S.R. 704.
Petition under Art.32 challenges vires of s.1(3)(b), notifications and scheme; prays for quashing notifications and mandamus not to apply scheme to petitioners' establishment.
Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952 applies to factories in Schedule I industries with 20+ persons, and other establishments with 20+ persons as specified by notification.

Employee defined in s.2(f) as any person employed for wages in any kind of work, manual or otherwise, in or in connection with work of establishment, getting wages directly or indirectly from employer, including through contractor.
S.5 authorises framing of Employees Provident Fund Scheme; contributions 6 1/4% of basic wages, DA, retaining allowance; DA includes cash value of food concession.
S.16 exempts certain co-operative societies and newly set up establishments (3/5 years grace).
S.17 empowers exemption if existing provident fund benefits not less favourable.

legal_issues.text: Whether s.1(3)(b) of the Act confers uncontrolled and uncanalised power on the Government.
Whether the Act was intended to apply only to mere wage-earners and not to salaried people, and thus notifications invalid as petitioners' employees are salaried.
Whether the scheme is discriminatory under Art.14 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: S.1(3)(b) confers uncontrolled and uncanalised power on the Government.
Act intended for mere wage-earners, not salaried people; petitioners' employees are salaried, not wage-earners.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Interpretation of Act and definition of employee

petitioner_arguments.text: Scheme bad under Art.14 as discriminatory.

court_reasoning.text: Powers under s.1(3)(b) not uncontrolled; Act directed to provident funds for employees in factories and establishments as social justice measure; policy to bring all kinds of employees; presumption against abuse by Government; s.17 provides guided exemptions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature indicated policy in preamble and provisions; no excessive delegation.

court_reasoning.text: No distinction between wage-earners and salaried; both emoluments for labour; Act makes no such distinction; basic wages defined broadly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Salary is remuneration for permanent engagement, but no principle distinguishes; Act applies regardless.

court_reasoning.text: No discrimination under Art.14; applies to all establishments except specified exemptions in s.16 (co-ops, new establishments) which are reasonable; s.17 ensures no less favourable benefits; all hotels/restaurants treated alike.

holdings.text: S.1(3)(b) valid; does not confer uncontrolled power.
Act applies to salaried employees as well as wage-earners; notifications valid.
No violation of Art.14; scheme not discriminatory.

precedents_cited.case_name: Eduard Mills Co. Ltd., Beawar v. State of Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Provisions of Minimum Wages Act similar; no uncanalised power in adding employments.

precedents_cited.case_name: Vasantal Maganbhai Sanjanuwala v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: No excessive delegation where policy enunciated in preamble and provisions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hamdard Dawakhana Wakf Lal Kuan, Delhi v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Excessive delegation where no criteria; unlike here where principles clear.

statutes_cited.name: Employees Provident Funds Act, 1952 (19 of 1952)
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions for applicability, scheme framing, exemptions upheld as constitutional.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petition under Art.32; challenges under Art.14 rejected.

outcome.summary: Court holds no substance in any contentions; s.1(3)(b), notifications and scheme constitutional; petition challenging vires dismissed.

key_quotes.text: In our opinion there is no substance in any one of these contentions.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The institution of provident fund for employees is too well-established to admit of any doubt about its utility as a measure of social justice.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Underlines policy and purpose of the Act.

key_quotes.text: This Court has repeatedly laid it down that where the discretion to apply the provisions of a particular statute is left with Government, it will be presumed that the discretion so vested in such a high authority will not be abused.
key_quotes.speaker: court
